query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Io era già da quell’ ombre partito, 2 e seguitava l’orme del mio duca, 3 quando di retro a me, drizzando ’l dito,
4 una gridò: «Ve’ che non par che luca 5 lo raggio da sinistra a quel di sotto, 6 e come vivo par che si conduca!».
query.result:
**English:**
1 I had already departed from those shadows, 2 and was following the footsteps of my guide, 3 when behind me, pointing his finger,
4 someone cried out: "See how the ray from the left 5 does not seem to shine on the one below, 6 and how he seems to walk as if he were alive!"
**Old English:**
1 Ic wæs ða fram ðæm sceаdum faren, 2 and folgode ðæs lærendes sporum, 3 ða æfter me, his finger teonde,
4 hrymde sum: "Loca, ne mæg ðæt leoht 5 ðæs wæteres gleam of ðæm wynstran beorgan, 6 and he lyfigende hine lædeð!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Li occhi rivolsi al suon di questo motto, 8 e vidile guardar per maraviglia 9 pur me, pur me, e ’l lume ch’era rotto.
query.result:
**English:**
7 I turned my eyes at the sound of this utterance, 8 and I saw her looking in wonder 9 only at me, only at me, and at the light that was broken.
**Old English:**
7 Þa ic mine eagan up gewende 8 and geseah ða wundrigende 9 me, me, and ðæt leoht ðe wæs torrofen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 «Perché l’animo tuo tanto s’impiglia», 11 disse ’l maestro, «che l’andare allenti? 12 che ti fa ciò che quivi si pispiglia?
13 Vien dietro a me, e lascia dir le genti: 14 sta come torre ferma, che non crolla 15 già mai la cima per soffiar di venti;
16 ché sempre l’omo in cui pensier rampolla 17 sovra pensier, da sé dilunga il segno, 18 perché la foga l’un de l’altro insolla».
query.result:
**English:**
10 "Why is your spirit so entangled," 11 said the master, "that you slow your pace? 12 What makes you heed the whispering here?
13 Come after me, and let people talk: 14 stand like a firm tower, whose top 15 never sways in the wind;
16 for the man in whom thought surges 17 upon thought, drives the mark further away, 18 because one thought hampers the other."
**Old English:**
10 "Hwi is ðin mod swa miclum geblissod," 11 cwæð se lareow, "ðæt ðu ðone gang ne ofest? 12 Hwæt ðe ðincas ðæt ðu her gehyrst?
13 Cumefterme,andlætðaleoðsprecan: 14 stand swa steap stænen tures, ðe næfre 15 his helm ne hlisteð for wæda geþræce;
16 forðæm ðe ðæs monnes mod ðe oft geþohte 17 ofer geþoht, ðone stede gehealdeð, 18 forðæm ðe ðæs anes ðæs oðres ne gifeð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Che potea io ridir, se non «Io vegno»? 20 Dissilo, alquanto del color consperso 21 che fa l’uom di perdon talvolta degno.
query.result:
**English:**
19 What could I say, except “I am coming”? 20 I said it, somewhat pale in color, 21 which sometimes makes a man worthy of forgiveness.
**Old English:**
19 Hwæt mihte ic ða sprecan, buton “Ic cume”? 20 Ic ðæt sæde, sumes ðæs hiwes gewanod, 21 ðe ðone wer oft ðæs forgifnesse wyrðne geðeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 E ’ntanto per la costa di traverso 23 venivan genti innanzi a noi un poco, 24 cantando ‘Miserere’ a verso a verso.
query.result:
**English:**
22 And meanwhile, along the hillside, 23 some people were coming towards us, 24 singing ‘Miserere’ verse by verse.
**Old English:**
22 And ða ðurh ðone munt be þam sidan 23 com folc ongeagn us lyt, 24 singende ‘Miserere’ fers forð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 E ’l mio maestro: «Voi potete andarne 32 e ritrarre a color che vi mandaro 33 che ’l corpo di costui è vera carne.
query.result:
**English:**
31 And my master: "You can go 32 and report to those who sent you 33 that this man's body is real flesh.
**Old English:**
31 And min lareow: "Ge magon faran 32 and secgan ðam ðe eow hider sendon 33 ðæt ðisses mannes lichama is soð flæsc."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Se per veder la sua ombra restaro, 35 com’ io avviso, assai è lor risposto: 36 fàccianli onore, ed esser può lor caro».
query.result:
**English:**
34 If they remain to see his shade, 35 as I believe, they have been answered enough: 36 let them honor him, and he may be dear to them."
**Old English:**
34 Gif hie willað his sceadu geseon, 35 swa ic wene, him is wel andwyrd: 36 do him ða weorðunga, and he him bið leof."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Vapori accesi non vid’ io sì tosto 38 di prima notte mai fender sereno, 39 né, sol calando, nuvole d’agosto,
40 che color non tornasser suso in meno; 41 e, giunti là, con li altri a noi dier volta, 42 come schiera che scorre sanza freno.
query.result:
**English:**
37 I never saw vapors so inflamed 38 cleave the serene air at the first hour of night, 39 nor clouds of August at sunset,
40 that they did not turn red again above; 41 and, having arrived there, they wheeled around with the others toward us, 42 like a troop that runs without rein.
**Old English:**
37 Ne geseah ic næfre fyres blæst swa hræd 38 æt frumsceaft nihtes fleogan on heofonum, 39 ne, sigel snyriende, sunnan setlganges,
40 ðæt hiw ne tornden heolfor bleoh weder; 41 and ða ðær cumen wæron, mid ðam oðrum us to, 42 swa mægen hryssum hweorfan butan gefean.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 «Questa gente che preme a noi è molta, 44 e vegnonti a pregar», disse ’l poeta: 45 «però pur va, e in andando ascolta».
query.result:
**English:**
43 "These people who press upon us are many, 44 and they come to pray to you," said the poet: 45 "but still go on, and listen as you go."
**Old English:**
43 "Þeos meniu ðe ðringð to us is fela, 44 and cumað to ðe biddan," cwæð se scop: 45 "ac ðeah ðu ga, and on gonge gehyr."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 «O anima che vai per esser lieta 47 con quelle membra con le quai nascesti», 48 venian gridando, «un poco il passo queta.
query.result:
**English:**
46 "O soul who go to be joyful 47 with those limbs with which you were born," 48 they came crying, "slow your pace a little.
**Old English:**
46 "Eala ðu sawl ðe gæst ðurh ðone lichoman 47 ðe ðu mid geboren wære," 48 cwædon ða clypigende, "þin færelt hwonlice."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Guarda s’alcun di noi unqua vedesti, 50 sì che di lui di là novella porti: 51 deh, perché vai? deh, perché non t’arresti?
52 Noi fummo tutti già per forza morti, 53 e peccatori infino a l’ultima ora; 54 quivi lume del ciel ne fece accorti,
55 sì che, pentendo e perdonando, fora 56 di vita uscimmo a Dio pacificati, 57 che del disio di sé veder n’accora».
query.result:
**English:**
49 See if you ever saw any of us, 50 so that you can carry news of him from here: 51 oh, why do you go? Oh, why don’t you stop?
52 We were all once forcibly killed, 53 and sinners until the very last hour; 54 here, a light from heaven made us aware,
55 so that, repenting and forgiving, we departed 56 from life, reconciled with God, 57 who inflames us with the desire to see him.
**Old English:**
49 Loca hwaðer ðu æfre gesawe sumne, 50 ðæt ðu ðær ðone bodan brohte: 51 a, hwi gæst ðu? a, hwi ne stentest ðu?
52 We wæron ealle ær ðurh ðone deað gedrehte, 53 and synfulle oð ðone siðestan timan; 54 ðær us ðæs heofonlican leohtes gerynu,
55 ðæt we ðurh ðone hreowsunge and ðurh ða forgifnesse, 56 of ðissum life eodon Gode geþafunge, 57 ðe ðæs wilnunga his gesyhðe us getrymð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 E io: «Perché ne’ vostri visi guati, 59 non riconosco alcun; ma s’a voi piace 60 cosa ch’io possa, spiriti ben nati,
61 voi dite, e io farò per quella pace 62 che, dietro a’ piedi di sì fatta guida, 63 di mondo in mondo cercar mi si face».
query.result:
**English:**
58 And I: "Why do I not recognize anyone 59 in your faces? But if it pleases you, 60 spirits well-born, to tell me something 61 that I can do, I will do it for that peace 62 which makes me search from world to world 63 behind the footsteps of such a guide."
**Old English:**
58 And ic: "Hwi ne oncnawe ic ænigne 59 on eowrum andwlitum? Ac gif hit eow licað 60 ænig ðing ðæt ic mæg, gastas wel geborene,
61 secgað, and ic wille wyrcan for ðære sibbe 62 ðe, æfter ðæs swiðran lareowes fotum, 63 of worulde to worulde me secan deð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 E uno incominciò: «Ciascun si fida 65 del beneficio tuo sanza giurarlo, 66 pur che ’l voler nonpossa non ricida.
query.result:
**English:**
64 And one began: "Everyone trusts 65 in your beneficence without swearing an oath, 66 as long as your will cannot but suffice.
**Old English:**
64 And an ða ongan ðus secgan: "Æghwylc ðe ðurh ðine gife truweð 65 butan aðe, ðe ðin willa næfre ne mæg awendan. 66 ðæt ðu ðone nelt forgolden ðe ðe ðus fæste lufað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Ond’ io, che solo innanzi a li altri parlo, 68 ti priego, se mai vedi quel paese 69 che siede tra Romagna e quel di Carlo,
70 che tu mi sie di tuoi prieghi cortese 71 in Fano, sì che ben per me s’adori 72 pur ch’i’ possa purgar le gravi offese.
query.result:
**English:**
67 And I, who speak alone before the others, 68 I beg you, if ever you see that land 69 that lies between Romagna and Charles's land,
70 that you be courteous with your prayers for me 71 in Fano, so that they pray well for me 72 so that I may purge my grave offenses.
**Old English:**
67 And ic, ðe ana sylf ætforan oðrum sprece, 68 bidde ðe, gif ðu æfre ðæt rice gesihst 69 ðe ys betwux Romandiolan and ðæs Caseres rice,
70 ðæt ðu sy ðinra gebedena milde 71 on Fane, ðæt hi wel for me gebiddon 72 ðæt ic mote ða hefigan synna gebetan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Quindi fu’ io; ma li profondi fóri 74 ond’ uscì ’l sangue in sul quale io sedea, 75 fatti mi fuoro in grembo a li Antenori,
76 là dov’ io più sicuro esser credea: 77 quel da Esti il fé far, che m’avea in ira 78 assai più là che dritto non volea.
query.result:
**English:**
73 Then I was; but the deep ditches 74 from which the blood flowed on which I sat 75 were made for me in the circle of the Antenori,
76 where I thought I was most secure: 77 he of Este had it done, who held me in hate 78 far more than justice wished.
**Old English:**
73 Þa wæs ic; ac ða deopan dicas 74 ðanon ðæt blod com on ðam ic sæt, 75 geworhte wæron me on ðara Antenora,
76 ðær ic wende wæron wærlicran: 77 ðæt dyde ða ðara ðe of Este wæs, ðe me on innan 78 micle ma ðonne riht wæs gram wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Ma s’io fosse fuggito inver’ la Mira, 80 quando fu’ sovragiunto ad Orïaco, 81 ancor sarei di là dove si spira.
query.result:
**English:**
79 But if I had fled towards the Mira, 80 when I was overtaken at Oriaco, 81 I would still be on the side where one breathes.
**Old English:**
79 Ac gif ic ða flugon ofer ða Mire, 80 ða ða ic oferfaren wæs æt ðam Oryacum, 81 ðonne wære ic gyt ðær ðær mon lif gæst.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Corsi al palude, e le cannucce e ’l braco 83 m’impigliar sì ch’i’ caddi; e lì vid’ io 84 de le mie vene farsi in terra laco».
query.result:
**English:**
82 I ran to the marsh, and the reeds and the mud 83 entangled me so that I fell; and there I saw 84 my veins forming a pool on the ground.
**Old English:**
82 Ic urnon ða to ðam mere, and ða reodas and ðæt lacu 83 me besæton swa ðæt ic feoll; and ðær ic ða geseah 84 of minum adrum ðone lacu on ðære eorðan geweorðan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Poi disse un altro: «Deh, se quel disio 86 si compia che ti tragge a l’alto monte, 87 con buona pïetate aiuta il mio!
88 Io fui di Montefeltro, io son Bonconte; 89 Giovanna o altri non ha di me cura; 90 per ch’io vo tra costor con bassa fronte».
query.result:
**English:**
85 Then another said: "Oh, may that desire 86 be fulfilled that draws you to the high mountain, 87 with good piety help mine!
88 I was from Montefeltro, I am Bonconte; 89 Giovanna or others do not care for me; 90 that's why I go among these with a bowed head."
**Old English:**
85 Þa cwæð oðer: "Ea, gif ðæt gewilnung 86 geweorðeð þe ðe tihð to ðam hean munte, 87 mid godre mildheortnesse gefylst ðu minne!
88 Ic wæs of Montefeltro, ic eom Bonconte; 89 Iohanne oððe oðre næfð nænne gieme be me; 90 forðæm ic fare betwux ðisum mid gebigedum heafde."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 E io a lui: «Qual forza o qual ventura 92 ti travïò sì fuor di Campaldino, 93 che non si seppe mai tua sepultura?».
query.result:
**English:**
91 And I to him: "What force or what fortune 92 drove you so far from Campaldino, 93 that your burial place was never known?"
**Old English:**
91 And ic to him: "Hwilc mægen oððe hwilc gesælð 92 ðe dræfde swa feor fram Campaldino, 93 ðæt ðin byrgen næfre man ne wiste?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
94 «Oh!», rispuos’ elli, «a piè del Casentino 95 traversa un’acqua c’ha nome l’Archiano, 96 che sovra l’Ermo nasce in Apennino.
query.result:
**English:**
94 "Oh!" he replied, "at the foot of Casentino 95 there flows a river called the Archiano, 96 which rises in the Apennines above the Arno.
**Old English:**
94 "Eala!" cwæð he, "æt ðæs Casentines fótum 95 ðurhflów ða ea ðe is haten ðe Archiano, 96 ðe ofer ðone Ermon on ðæm Apennine spryngð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Là ’ve ’l vocabol suo diventa vano, 98 arriva’ io forato ne la gola, 99 fuggendo a piede e sanguinando il piano.
query.result:
**English:**
97 There where its vocabulary fails, 98 I arrived, pierced in the throat, 99 fleeing on foot and staining the plain with blood.
**Old English:**
97 Þær ðær his word geweorðað wæstm, 98 ic com ðær ðurh ðone hals forwundod, 99 fleonde on fotum and ðone feld blodigende.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Quivi perdei la vista e la parola; 101 nel nome di Maria fini’, e quivi 102 caddi, e rimase la mia carne sola.
query.result:
**English:**
100 There I lost sight and speech; 101 in the name of Mary I ended, and there 102 I fell, and my flesh remained alone.
**Old English:**
100 Þær ic forleas gewit and word; 101 on Marian naman ic me belaf, and þær 102 ic feoll, and min flæsc anad.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Io dirò vero, e tu ’l ridì tra ’ vivi: 104 l’angel di Dio mi prese, e quel d’inferno 105 gridava: “O tu del ciel, perché mi privi?
106 Tu te ne porti di costui l’etterno 107 per una lagrimetta che ’l mi toglie; 108 ma io farò de l’altro altro governo!”.
query.result:
**English:**
103 I will tell you the truth, and you repeat it among the living: 104 the angel of God took me, and the one from hell 105 cried out: “O you of heaven, why do you deprive me?
106 You carry away from me the eternal soul of this man 107 for a single tear that he sheds; 108 but I will make other arrangements for him!”
**Old English:**
103 Ic secge ðe soð, and ðu hit secge ðam lybbendum: 104 ðæs Godes engel nam me, and ðæs helle gast 105 cleopode: “Eala ðu of heofenum, hwi benimeð ðu me?
106 ðu læt ðisne of minum gewealde faran 107 for ðære anre teare ðe he geweop; 108 ac ic sceal ðisne oðrum wisan bewerian!”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Ben sai come ne l’aere si raccoglie 110 quell’ umido vapor che in acqua riede, 111 tosto che sale dove ’l freddo il coglie.
query.result:
**English:**
109 I know well how in the air is gathered 110 that moist vapor which turns back into water, 111 as soon as it rises to where the cold seizes it.
**Old English:**
109 Ic wat ful georne hu ne on lyfte gæð 110 se wæta wylm ðe on wæter bið, 111 sona swa he gæð ðær him ceald begegnð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Giunse quel mal voler che pur mal chiede 113 con lo ’ntelletto, e mosse il fummo e ’l vento 114 per la virtù che sua natura diede.
query.result:
**English:**
112 That evil will arrived, which only seeks evil, 113 with its intellect, and moved the smoke and the wind 114 by the power that its nature gave it.
**Old English:**
112 ða com se yfla will ðe ðurh yfel wile 113 mid ðam mode, and ðone smec and ðone wind 114 ðurh ða mihte ðe him his gecynd geaf.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Indi la valle, come ’l dì fu spento, 116 da Pratomagno al gran giogo coperse 117 di nebbia; e ’l ciel di sopra fece intento,
118 sì che ’l pregno aere in acqua si converse; 119 la pioggia cadde, e a’ fossati venne 120 di lei ciò che la terra non sofferse;
121 e come ai rivi grandi si convenne, 122 ver’ lo fiume real tanto veloce 123 si ruinò, che nulla la ritenne.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Then, as day faded, the valley 116 from Pratomagno to the great mountain pass 117 was covered with fog; and the sky above 118 grew so dark that the heavy air turned to water; 119 rain fell, and the ditches were filled 120 with the overflow from the land;
121 and as is the nature of large streams, 122 the water rushed so swiftly toward 123 the royal river that nothing could stop it.
**Old English:**
115 Þa wæs ðære dene, swa ðæs dæges wæs, 116 of ðam Pratomagno oð ðone miclan munt, 117 neowolcen oferwrigen; and se heofon selfa 118 swa ðic wæs geworden, ðæt ðæs lyftes wæta 119 on rine gewende; and ða regnscuru feoll, 120 and ða dicas wurdon ðæs wætres fulle,
121 swa hit ðara miclena ea bysnung is, 122 ðæt hit swa hraðe ðone cynelican ea 123 gesohte, ðæt hit nænig ðing ne belaf.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Lo corpo mio gelato in su la foce 125 trovò l’Archian rubesto; e quel sospinse 126 ne l’Arno, e sciolse al mio petto la croce
127 ch’i’ fe’ di me quando ’l dolor mi vinse; 128 voltòmmi per le ripe e per lo fondo, 129 poi di sua preda mi coperse e cinse».
query.result:
**English:**
124 My frozen body at the mouth of the river 125 the cruel Archian found; and he pushed it 126 into the Arno, and loosed from my chest the cross
127 that I made of myself when pain overcame me; 128 he turned me over and over on the banks and in the depths, 129 then covered and encircled me with his prey.
**Old English:**
124 Min lichama gecyled æt ðære mûðan 125 fand se hearda Archian; and se ðone âscode 126 on ðone Earn, and âlŷsde of mînum breostum ðæt rôd
127 ðe ic geworhte of me sylfum ðâ me se dolg ofercom; 128 bewende mec ofer ðâ oferðas and ofer ðone grund, 129 siððan mid his præde mec oferwreah and beclypte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 «Deh, quando tu sarai tornato al mondo 131 e riposato de la lunga via», 132 seguitò ’l terzo spirito al secondo,
133 «ricorditi di me, che son la Pia; 134 Siena mi fé, disfecemi Maremma: 135 salsi colui che ’nnanellata pria
136 disposando m’avea con la sua gemma».
query.result:
**English:**
130 "Ah, when you have returned to the world 131 and rested from your long journey," 132 the third spirit continued to the second,
133 "remember me, who am Pia; 134 Siena made me, Maremma unmade me: 135 he knows who, having first encircled me
136 with his gem, had me as his bride."
**Old English:**
130 "Ea, ðonne ðu to ðære worulde becumest 131 and ðære langne strete gereste," 132 ða ðridda gast ðam oðrum sæde,
133 "ðu ðonne ðinre Pían geðence, 134 ðe Siena geworhte and Maremma fordyde: 135 ðæt wat se ðe ða gyldnan hring
136 ærest gesceafte ða he mec him to wife hæfde."
